description: Pipe supports and seismic bracing requirements

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of pipe hangers in sprinkler systems?
options: To support the weight of piping and maintain proper slope
questions.explanation: Hangers support the weight of pipe, water, and connected components while maintaining the designed slope for proper drainage.

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for hangers on 1-inch pipe?
questions.explanation: Pipe 1-inch through 1-1/2 inch requires hangers at maximum 12-foot intervals. Larger pipe may have 15-foot spacing.

questions.question: What is the maximum hanger spacing for 2-inch and larger pipe?
questions.explanation: Pipe 2-inch and larger has a maximum hanger spacing of 15 feet under normal conditions.

questions.question: What must hangers be attached to?
options: Building structure capable of supporting five times the weight
questions.explanation: Hangers must be attached to the building structure with a safety factor of 5:1 to support the pipe, water, and system loads.

questions.question: Can sprinkler piping hang from other sprinkler piping?
options: Yes, any piping can support other piping
Only if specifically designed for the additional load
questions.explanation: Piping may only support other piping if specifically designed for the combined loading, with properly sized hangers and attachments.

questions.question: What type of hanger is commonly used for horizontal runs?
options: All of the above are approved types
questions.explanation: Various hanger types are used including ring hangers, U-hooks, clevis hangers, and others. The type used depends on the application.

questions.question: What is the maximum distance from the end of pipe to the last hanger?
questions.explanation: The last hanger should be within half the maximum spacing distance from the end of the pipe to provide proper support.

questions.question: What is seismic bracing?
options: Lateral restraint to prevent pipe movement during earthquakes
questions.explanation: Seismic bracing provides lateral (sideways) restraint to prevent excessive pipe movement and damage during earthquake shaking.

questions.question: Where is seismic bracing required?
options: In seismic design categories meeting code thresholds
questions.explanation: Seismic bracing is required in areas with significant seismic risk as defined by the building code (Seismic Design Categories C and higher).

questions.question: What are the two types of seismic braces?
questions.explanation: Seismic braces are installed in two directions: longitudinal (along the pipe) and transverse/lateral (perpendicular to the pipe).

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for transverse (lateral) seismic braces?
options: Based on calculation, typically 40 feet maximum
questions.explanation: Transverse brace spacing is typically 40 feet maximum but varies based on pipe size, system configuration, and seismic zone.

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for longitudinal seismic braces?
options: Based on calculation, typically 80 feet maximum
questions.explanation: Longitudinal brace spacing is typically 80 feet maximum, twice the transverse spacing, since longitudinal loads are generally less severe.

questions.question: What is a 4-way brace?
options: A single brace assembly providing both longitudinal and transverse restraint
questions.explanation: A 4-way brace provides restraint in all horizontal directions (longitudinal and transverse) from a single location.

questions.question: What is a flexible coupling (seismic coupling)?
options: A coupling allowing pipe movement without failure
questions.explanation: Flexible couplings allow controlled pipe movement at joints during seismic events, preventing pipe breaks at connections.

questions.question: Where are seismic separation assemblies required?
options: Where piping crosses building seismic joints
questions.explanation: Seismic separation assemblies (flexible connections) are required where piping crosses building movement/seismic joints.

questions.question: What clearance is required around piping passing through walls/floors?
options: Clearance or flexible fitting to allow movement
questions.explanation: Piping through walls and floors needs clearance (typically 2 inches) or flexible fittings to allow for building movement during seismic events.

questions.question: What is the zone of influence for a seismic brace?
options: The length of pipe effectively restrained by one brace
questions.explanation: Zone of influence is the pipe length that a single brace effectively restrains, determining spacing between braces.

questions.question: What must hangers and braces be made of?
options: Listed materials with appropriate load ratings
questions.explanation: Hangers and seismic braces must be listed and rated for the loads they will carry, with appropriate materials for the environment.

questions.question: Can wire hangers be used for sprinkler systems?
options: Only for armover pipes to individual sprinklers under certain conditions
questions.explanation: Wire can only be used for armover support to individual sprinklers meeting specific criteria - limited length, specific wire size, etc.

questions.question: What is the minimum rod size for hangers?
options: 3/8 inch for pipes up to 4 inch
Based on pipe size per NFPA 13 tables
questions.explanation: Minimum hanger rod size is specified by NFPA 13 based on pipe size - typically 3/8" for smaller pipe, larger for big pipe.

questions.question: What angle limitation applies to hanger rods?
options: Not to exceed 30 degrees from vertical
questions.explanation: Hanger rods should be installed vertically or as close to vertical as possible, not exceeding 30 degrees from vertical.

questions.question: What is required at changes in pipe direction?
options: Support within specified distance of the direction change
questions.explanation: Additional support is required near changes in direction to handle the additional stress at fittings and directional changes.

questions.question: How is seismic load calculated for bracing?
options: Based on pipe weight and seismic coefficient (Cp factor)
questions.explanation: Seismic loads are calculated using pipe/water weight multiplied by seismic coefficients (Cp) from building codes for the location.

questions.question: What is the horizontal force coefficient (Cp) typically used for?
questions.explanation: Cp (horizontal force coefficient) is used to calculate the lateral seismic force the bracing must resist: F = Cp Ã— Weight.

questions.question: What is the typical angle for sway braces?
questions.explanation: Sway braces should be installed at 45 degrees from vertical or less for effective lateral load resistance.

questions.question: What is the uplift resistance requirement for hangers?
options: Must resist upward force during seismic events
questions.explanation: Hangers must resist both downward (gravity) and upward (seismic uplift) forces to prevent pipe separation during earthquakes.

questions.question: What NFPA 13 appendix provides seismic calculation guidance?
questions.explanation: Appendix E of NFPA 13 provides detailed guidance and worksheets for seismic design of fire sprinkler systems.

questions.question: What is required when a brace fails load testing?
options: Brace must be replaced or reinforced to meet requirements
questions.explanation: Failed braces must be replaced or reinforced to achieve the required load resistance before system acceptance.

questions.question: What is the C-clamp prohibition?
options: C-clamps cannot be used for seismic bracing to the structure
questions.explanation: C-clamps generally cannot be used for seismic brace attachments as they may slip under dynamic loading. Welded or bolted connections are required.

questions.question: What is the restraint requirement for risers?
options: Must be restrained at top and intervals to prevent lateral movement
questions.explanation: Risers must be restrained at top, bottom, and intermediate locations as needed to prevent excessive lateral movement.

questions.question: Can powder-actuated fasteners be used for seismic bracing?
options: Only when listed and installed per manufacturer specifications
questions.explanation: Powder-actuated fasteners may be used when specifically listed for the application and installed per the manufacturer's instructions.

questions.question: What documentation is required for seismic bracing?
options: Locations shown on drawings with calculations supporting design
questions.explanation: Seismic bracing locations must be shown on system drawings with supporting calculations for loads and brace adequacy.

questions.question: What is required for trapeze-type hangers?
options: Must have lateral restraint in both directions
questions.explanation: Trapeze hangers supporting multiple pipes need lateral restraint since they can swing. Proper bracing or rigid attachment is required.

questions.question: What is the hanger requirement near sprinklers?
options: Branch line supported to prevent sprinkler movement
questions.explanation: Branch lines must be adequately supported so that sprinklers don't move excessively, but a hanger isn't required at each sprinkler.

questions.question: What material limitation applies to seismic brace components?
options: Only ferrous materials meeting specific standards
questions.explanation: Seismic brace components must be listed and meet specific material and load rating requirements for the application.
